Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Negative Effects of High Frequency Trading and Transparency in Dynamic Markets

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds research on the design of dynamic markets under conditions of asymmetric information. The designer has a limited set of instruments, and once the design is established the market operates as a competitive market. The goal of the project is to determine how restrictions on the timing of market transactions or mandating transparency about market buy and sell offers affect market outcomes and the overall efficiency of trade in the market.

The project has four distinct components. The first compares efficiency of market outcomes for different designs that differ in terms of how frequently the market is open for trades. For example, the team compares outcomes in markets in which buyers make continuous offers to outcomes in markets where after the first offer there is a lock-up period during which no trades can be made. The research establishes conditions under which this kind of trade restriction improves the overall functioning of the market. The second component considers the pros and cons of transparency of past offers in dynamic markets. The research demonstrates that market equilibria are very different when past rejected offers are public information. Less transparency results in more efficient trade. The third component considers possible government interventions in markets with dynamic adverse selection. The results suggest that a policy of holding periodic auctions and subsidizing some initial trades can improve market efficiency. The final component considers competition between marketplaces.

The research provides broader impact by shedding new light on the consequences of high-frequency trading, transparency of order flows and certain market institutions found in financial markets. The results will be useful for evaluation of government policy, from regulation of financial markets and competition between marketplaces to a direct intervention by purchases of assets in so called 'frozen' markets to re-establish liquidity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work supported by this grant has led to several papers that provide insights about functioning of dynamic asset markets. The basic setup considers a seller of a durable asset who is privately informed about the quality of the asset. She faces a competitive fringe of buyers who for any given asset quality value the asset more than the seller but, crucially, are uniformed about the quality of the asset. Both buyers and sellers are
rational. Thus, expecting a certain equilibrium-price path the seller optimally chooses when to sell and since buyers compete whenever there is trade, the prices must coincide with the average value of the assets sold.


In our first paper, Costs and Benefits of Dynamic Trading in a Lemons Market, we have considered how the equilibrium is affected by different market designs that restrict how often the market participants can trade. The main takeaway is that some restrictions to continuous trading are beneficial because they force pooling of trades in some periods and that reduces adverse selection and the connected inefficiency.


This insight helped us develop new results on optimal government interventions in “Government Interventions in a Dynamic Market with Adverse Selection” (published in the Journal of Economic Theory). In that paper the market is opened continuously but the government can influence timing of trades by a tax and subsidy policy. The main results are that a) early and concentrated in time subsidies tend to be better than subsidies spread over time b) late subsidies, despite helping market efficiency at the time of policy, delay trade in expectation of the future subsidy, and can in net destroy surplus.


Finally, we have analyzed also the issue of transparency in dynamic markets. As a result of the recent financial crisis there has been a strong regulatory push towards more "transparent" markets. In “Transparency and Distressed Sales Under Asymmetric Information” (joint with Aniko Oery and the two PIs, published at Theoretical Economics) we study the implications of making rejected offers transparent to future market participants. We compare two opposite information structures: transparent (public offers), in which all buyers observe past price offers and opaque (private offers), in which every period new buyers make offers and they do not observe past rejected offers.


The main takeaway from this paper is that less transparency (of rejected offers) tends to improve efficiency of the market. The intuition is that sellers have incentives to use rejected offers as a signal of high value to future buyers. As a result, buyers worry more about adverse selection when offers are public and that reduces the amount of (efficient) trade.

Adverse Selection and Reallocation:    In response to aggregate shocks, an economy's resources need to be constantly reallocated. This reallocation often involves a trade from the owner of the resource, who no longer needs it, to buyers who can put it to better use. Productive resources are naturally heterogeneous in their quality, and therefore informational asymmetries between market participants can lead to market failures. In a paper co-authored with Brett Green and Dimitris Papanikolaou: Adverse selection, slow moving capital and misallocation (Published in Journal of Financial Economics 2015), we incorporate these considerations into a dynamic model of resource reallocation with heterogeneous capital.    Even though much of the language we use refers to physical capital, the model is general and its implications are also applicable to human capital. Owners of higher quality resources hold on to them longer as a way to signal to the market their quality. Thus, in equilibrium, prices in the market start low and raise gradually as better and better assets are traded. In this way, adverse selection leads to slow moving capital and persistent misallocation of resources. Our model would suggest that misallocation would be more prevalent in developing countries where there is less ability to write enforceable contracts to mitigate the adverse selection problems. This is also consistent with the growing consensus among economists that misallocation is large enough to explain a significant part of the TFP gap across rich and poor countries.
